body: I think it "could" help when there are multiple forks if each fork pulls independently. That said, I'm not sure how many forks are needed to see a perfect gain over SyncFork.
BTW, you can now run JMH benchmarks via `./gradlew jmh`

@htran1 In response to your general comment:

> General comment is that StateStore should not know about 'current'...
> The StateStore should exposed APIs used at the DatasetStateStore level to access the last modified state.

The StateStore does expose an API to access current: `getCurrent` and `getAllCurrent`.  Additionally, the `createAlias` API has been removed.  In order to support a seamless upgrade, StateStore, also supports the prior `get*` calls being called with a filename like `current`.  In this case it will perform the same as the `getCurrent`/`getAllCurrent` calls.  The logic behind this is that I cannot be sure that there are no dependencies from third-party libraries on the existing `get*` calls.  By making the change in this way, we can get rid of the `current` aliased files, while still ensuring existing code will work. We can publish in release note that callers need to upgrade to the latest API.

> ... DatasetStateStore should not query directly.

If desired, the logic of `MysqlDatasetStateStore.getLatestDatasetStatesByUrns` can be pushed down into `MysqlStateStore`, if you feel strongly about that.
Test failed in gobblin-cluster module which is not related to this commit.
@htran1 I don't think that test failure is due to my PR.  It seems to be a problem with line 197 in `GobblinClusterKillTest`: ` _clusterWorkers[0].disconnectHelixManager();`.
It's probably best for @ibuenros to review. I am not sure what ConfigurationKeys.SOURCE_FILEBASED_FS_SNAPSHOT is .

`ConfigurationKeys.SOURCE_FILEBASED_FS_SNAPSHOT` is the list of files seen at a given time on the source.  Basically, when a job runs it gets a list of all files on the source.  This becomes the `SOURCE_FILEBASED_FS_SNAPSHOT` for this run.  Then it checks for a previous run.  If one exists, it looks for the previous run's `SOURCE_FILEBASED_FS_SNAPSHOT` and diffs it with the current one.  Any files that are in the current one and not in the previous are files which will be ingested.

There are two changes here:

1. Ensure that when we log the `SOURCE_FILEBASED_FILES_TO_PULL` that we don't produce an exceedingly large string.  This is done by limiting the number of files we will print to 2000.
1. Ensure that the files to pull from workunits we are retrying are in the previous snapshot

Updated with new SerializedRecord (w content-type concept). One thing that is kind of confusing: SerializedRecordWithMetadata can be read two different ways: SerializedRecord With Metadata, which is what it actually is, or Serialized (RecordWithMetadata). Don't know if there is a better naming scheme so it's obvious how to break the phrases up.

@lbendig : Here is a simpler approach to accomplish this. I looked at KafkaAvroExtractor and followed the pattern from there. 

First in KafkaDeserializerExtractor: 
 cache the latest schema for the topic in a private member variable (say this.latestSchema) using the same strategy as KafkaAvroExtractor. 

Then in KafkaDeserializerExtractor::decodeRecord

First get the native deserialized object from the deserializer
Object deserialized = this.kafkaDeserializer.deserialize(this.topicName, messageAndOffset.getMessageBytes());

Then coerce this object to be compatible with the latest schema using gobblin.util.AvroUtils
You might have to do an instanceof GenericRecord check before this.

GenericRecord upconvertedRecord = gobblin.util.AvroUtils.convertRecordSchema((GenericRecord) deserialized, this.latestSchema)
return upconvertedRecord;


This should result in a much smaller code patch and hopefully accomplishes the same results.
